summary: On November 17, 2017, the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania entered a final judgment against defendant Jay Edwin "Jay" Appellant, Jr. of Lancaster County, Pennsylvania, ordering him to comply with the mandatory registration and reporting requirements of the Pennsylvania Department of Justice.  The court's order, which was entered on December 20, 2012, requires defendants to register as a Tier III sexual offender by the time they are sentenced.  According to the SEC's complaint filed in federal court in Philadelphia on September 17, 2016, Appellants, then 16 years of age, was charged with violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities and Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 17(b) thereunder, and the registration provisions of the federal securities laws. The court also imposed a penalty of $1,206.76, which is substantially higher than the penalty imposed by the state at the time he committed the alleged crimes.  Appelant has agreed to the settlement without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC complaint. The settlement is subject to court approval.  In a parallel action, the Pennsylvania Attorney General's Office today announced that it has filed an emergency action to halt the pending litigation. The SEC's continuing investigation is being conducted in the Philadelphia Regional Office and the case is being supervised by C.J. Kerstetter. The litigation will be led by Jennifer C. Barry and supervised by Amy C. Welshhans. The case has been supervised by Joseph G. Sansone, Chief of the Philadelphia Division of Criminal Investigations.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 1223 (January 13, 2017).  The SEC appreciates the assistance of the UPA's Office of Inspector General, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Philadelphia Office of Child and Family Education, the PA Department of Health and Human Services, the FBI's Philadelphia Field Office, the Criminal Investigations Division, the State Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, the Internal Revenue Service, the Department of Education's Retail Strategy Task Force, the Division of Justice's Cyber Unit, the Office of the Inspector General's Criminal Justice Division, and other assistance in this matter. The Division of Enforcement has issued anÂ Investigative AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment in an investment using the free and simple search tool onÂ Securities.gov.Â The SEC's investigation has been conducted in conjunction with the Pennsylvania Office of Criminal Justice's Office. The investigation was conducted by Michael J. Karpel and Carol A. McKinley of the SEC Enforcement Division's Philadelphia Office, and was supervised by Scott A. Kasper.
